metadata.title: Data Science — What Exactly Does it Mean? | by Asad Mumtaz | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Data Science — What Exactly Does it Mean?
metadata.description: A thorough introduction to data science, machine learning, and its various sub-domains

all_paragraphs: Data Science — this buzzword has been around for quite some time now. Those who have not had practical exposure to data science or its various sub-domains might think of it as a panacea or magic wand, that can answer any business question or predict anything irrespective of the underlying assumptions or requirements.

I do not claim to be a data scientist, but I have been fortunate enough to be involved in one way or another with various aspects of data science. It is an extremely complex, broad, and inter-disciplinary field — that encompasses mathematics, statistics, programming, databases, big data, data analysis, machine learning, and data architecture, to name a few.
Someone very succinctly conveyed this reality as:
A data scientist is better at mathematics/statistics than any software engineer, and is better at software engineering than any mathematician or statistician.

I do not intend to bore you with a formal definition and explanation of data science; however, the presence of the word ‘science’ in ‘data science’ should be enough for someone to appreciate the scientific intricacies implicit in the field of data science.

My intention here is to try to list down and provide a high-level summary of all the significant sub-domains, concepts, and techniques under data science to hopefully act as a reference guide for any aspiring data scientist or someone remotely interested in data science.
When explaining the data science field to someone unfamiliar with it, I usually prefer to break it down into three extensive areas:
Before we dig deep into each of them individually, let me caveat this article with the fact that
No data science project can be successful without intimate domain knowledge of the particular problem a data scientist is trying to solve.

Some experts have quite rightly acknowledged that a good data scientist needs to have a sufficiently deep understanding of three broad domains: mathematics and statistics, computer science or programming, and domain knowledge. Without an intricate understanding of domain knowledge, one will be unable to efficiently and effectively tailor, adapt, and use all the various tools and techniques at his/her disposal.
I aim to cover the first two domains of data science here: mathematics and statistics, and computer science/programming.
Having laid the essential groundwork, let us understand a bit more about what is involved in data science.

I get you — it is not sexy to start with perhaps the most boring of academic topics. But the fact remains that an understanding of various mathematical and statistical models forms the basis for the majority of machine learning and deep learning algorithms.

One might be able to implement a machine learning model without any knowledge of underlying statistical concepts. However, he/she would be unable to debug it, draw meaningful insights or inferences, fine-tune it, interpret the limitations of the result, or validate it effectively.
Some of the standard mathematical and statistical concepts utilized in data science are:
Probability theory, including Bayesian statistics, hypothesis testing, various probability distributions, etc.

Some of the standard statistical tests and procedures include regression analysis (linear, logistic, polynomial, non-linear, multivariate, binomial, multinomial, etc.), analysis of variance (ANOVA), Chi-squared tests, correlation analysis, Student’s t-test, time series, conjoint analysis, etc.
Statistical decision theory — making decisions in conjunction with statistical knowledge, thereby shedding light on some of the uncertainties involved in decision-making, e.g., confusion matrices
Data scientists need a platform or an environment to implement all the above mathematical computations and models. Programming languages come to our rescue.

In addition to specific special-purpose programming languages that are dedicated predominantly to the data science domain, several general-purpose programming languages have also evolved to include data science specific functionalities through various open-source packages and functions.
Some of the most common and popular programming languages used by data scientists are:

This is where the real fun begins — however, there are several ways in which all the possible concepts and techniques can be classified under. For this write-up, I will try to keep the classifications generic enough, while my next article will focus on three major perspectives to approach various machine learning concepts.
As I alluded to earlier, all the machine learning algorithms hereunder are based on one or more proven mathematical concepts.
Supervised machine learning algorithms can be further divided into regression and classification algorithms.
These algorithms predict a continuous numerical variable based on input variables (called features) from the data fed to the algorithm and comprise of:
These algorithms classify or categorize the output variable (called target) into a given number of classes. The most common and well-known classification algorithms are:
Majority of the other supervised machine learning algorithms can be applied in both regression and classification problems, for example:

Unsupervised machine learning algorithms try to identify and predict previously undetected patterns in a data set with no pre-existing labels; in other words, we do not know the correct values of the target variable beforehand.

For example, a company can implement an unsupervised machine learning algorithm to identify and group its customers together into unique segments based on specific shared characteristics. As you can imagine, the customers did not have a pre-existing label classifying them into a particular segment — unsupervised algorithms come to our rescue.
Unsupervised machine learning algorithms can be further divided into the following:

These algorithms group or classify similar data points into specific groups — predominantly through some similarity or distance measures. In theory, the observations within a group/cluster will exhibit similar properties that would be different from those in another cluster.
Some of the standard clustering algorithms include:

Anomaly detection is the process of identifying outliers from a given data set that are considered significantly different from the majority of the observations. Anomaly detection is heavily utilized in fraud detection, structural defects, medical conditions, etc.
Popular unsupervised machine learning algorithms for anomaly detection include:

These methodologies aim to reduce the number of features (input variables) where they are in hundreds or even thousands to select the best predictable features for our algorithm, without losing material information and while maintaining (or potentially improving) our model’s performance.
Some of the dimensionality reduction techniques include:

Dimensionality reduction can also be achieved through correlation analysis (remove highly correlated features), Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) analysis, backward feature elimination, and forward feature construction, among others.

Time series forecasting adds a unique time dimension to our data set, thereby bringing in temporal dependencies between the observations. In traditional machine learning algorithms, the future is predicted based on historical observations where all prior observations are treated equally. However, a time series dataset is different in that it adds an explicit order dependence between observations: a time dimension.

A time-series data can be both univariate (e.g., historical daily rainfall or daily sales of a product) or multivariate (e.g., past regular sales of 2 products). Further, time-series forecasting can be both a single-step or multi-step prediction. Single-step forecasting involves forecasting just the one next variable in the future, while multi-step time series forecasting predicts multiple future values. The further ahead we predict, the wider would be our confidence intervals.
Following are some of the statistical and machine learning concepts that are generally used in practice for time series forecasting:

Recommendation system algorithms do precisely what the name suggests: recommend the most relevant items to a user based on his/her consumption history, preferences, or both. Items could be movies to watch (Netflix), songs to listen (Spotify), products to buy (Amazon and eBay).
Let us briefly go over the principal recommendation systems used nowadays:

Collaborative filtering methods rely solely on a user’s previous interactions (number of likes, user ratings, purchases, time spent reading an article, etc.) with the items in question. The basic premise is this: if both my friend and I like a particular movie (based on our ratings), I would most likely want to watch another film that was liked by my friend.
Collaborative filtering methods can be further sub-divided into the following:

Content-based filtering methods build upon collaborative filtering methods by incorporating additional nuance around user profile, item description, or both. For example, a content-based movie recommendation algorithm can utilize my age, gender, and location (user profile) or the movie category, language, and lead actors (item description) to recommend my next movie. Bayesian classifiers, cluster analysis, decision trees, and artificial neural networks are generally used to estimate the likelihood of a user to like an item.

Hybrid systems utilize both collaborative and content-based filtering to build a recommendation system. Netflix is an excellent example of the use of hybrid recommender systems. Its recommendations are a combination of watch and search habits of similar users (i.e., collaborative filtering) together with recommending movies that share characteristics with films that a user has rated highly in the past (content-based filtering). Refer to this article for further details on Netflix’s Recommender System.

Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) are inspired by how a biological brain functions to undertake complex decision-making processes with the help of biological neurons. There are some overlaps in the literature between ANN and deep learning. However, for this article, I will consider an ANN to be a network that comprises of only three layers of neurons: an input layer, a hidden layer (where all data and information processing is carried out by a machine learning algorithm) and an output layer. ANNs are designed to learn or adapt themselves iteratively and are extensively used for finding patterns or identifying images that are far too complex or time consuming for a human to program.
ANNs learn by example, as stated by Howard Rheingold:
The neural network is this kind of technology that is not an algorithm, it is a network that has weights on it, and you can adjust the weights so that it learns. You teach it through trials.

Deep machine learning or deep neural networks are advanced ANNs with multiple hidden layers, i.e., information can be iteratively processed through machine learning algorithms by each hidden neuron layer to map the input layer more effectively to the output layer.
Some of the most common types of deep neural networks are:

CNNs are mostly used in image or pattern recognition, classification, and analysis problems. CNNs were first introduced in 1998 as LeNet-5. They differ from regular neural networks (in which, usually, each layer is fully connected to all neurons in the previous layer) — the layers are organized in three dimensions (width, height, and depth) and that the neurons in a layer are only connected a small region in the next layer. As the name suggests, the layers in a CNN are convolutional layers that use a convolution operation on the input before passing on to the next layer.
Some of the leading CNN model implementations being used nowadays in their respective domains are:

Introduced in 2014, GANs are algorithmic architectures that use two neural networks in an adversarial manner to generate new, synthetic data points that closely mimic real data. They are used widely in image generation, video generation, and voice generation.

GANs work by generating new data instances by one neural network (the generator), while the other evaluates them for authenticity (the discriminator). Accordingly, the discriminator decides whether each instance of data that it reviews belongs to the actual training dataset or not. Refer to the original paper here.

RNNs are a particular type of neural network designed for sequence problems. They differ from other deep neural networks in that the output from the previous step is an input for the next step (thereby being recurrent).

Therefore, in addition to the traditional learning involved during the model training step, RNNs have an additional learning step whereby they remember things learned from prior input while generating an output. RNNs are used for handwriting recognition, speech recognition, time-series predictions, natural language processing, and others.
Some specific neural networks based on RNNs are:

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a broad term that encompasses several facets of computational processing of human languages, be it processing a text input (translations, sentiment analysis, etc.), or generating human-understandable text through algorithms (natural language generation, automatic summarization, chatbots, etc.).

Although NLP algorithms and methodologies are based on ANN and deep networks, I have decided to elaborate on NLP separately since the majority of the latest NLP algorithms comprise of two or more different deep learning algorithms together (ANN, RNN, CNN, etc.).

NLP related functions performed through deep machine learning algorithms include machine translation, parsing, tagging, named entity recognition, natural language generation, chatbots, sentiment analysis, summarizing, etc.
Some common pre-trained and otherwise NLP related models and libraries include:

Although the following support activities are theoretically not classified as part of data science (as each one of them is an independent field of study and domain in themselves), they usually complement machine learning tasks by making our work more efficient and effective.

Although data engineering is a pretty broad field, for the sake of brevity here, I will briefly go over concepts such as data collection, ingestion, and cleaning. All these tasks form a cornerstone for any machine learning pipeline — there is no machine learning without data that is clean and transformed in a way that can be used by our ML algorithms.
The main objective of data engineering is to collect data and transform it in such a way that it is readable and usable by machine learning algorithms.
Search Engines are NoSQL database management systems that facilitate searching for data content. Some of the oft-used search and analytics engines include:
Data/web scraping is the process of collecting or extracting data from websites through tools such as Scrapy, Beautiful Soup, and Selenium.

Data ingestion is the process of collecting data from various sources (maybe through search engines or web scraping) into one central point (a data lake or a data warehouse, for example) before performing advanced data analytics or utilizing it for machine learning purposes.

Data cleansing or cleaning forms a critical component of the machine learning pipeline (remember GIGO?). It involves removing duplicate, erroneous or irrelevant entries, unifying labels, converting them into a proper format, handling missing data (excluding them altogether or imputing them through other means), and other similar processes to make raw data usable by our ML algorithms.
Data storage, as the name implies, is simply the process of storing data in a reusable and easily accessible form. Some of the traditional and non-traditional data storage methodologies are:

Not all data science projects involve big data, but in case yours does, the following are some of the related frameworks and solutions. Most of the following are distributed processing frameworks that are inherently capable of storing, handling, and processing large volumes of structured and unstructured data in a parallel fashion.

Hadoop is a set of open-source programs, tools, and procedures (i.e., a complete big data framework or ecosystem) that serves as a backbone of big data operations. Developed by Apache, it is an open-source framework; however, various third-party vendors specialize in Hadoop deployments tuned to your specific organizational requirements.
Some of the most common modules of Hadoop are:

Spark is another big data ecosystem that is open-source and developed by Apache. You might be wondering why Apache developed Spark when there was already a big data framework available in the form of Hadoop. Spark is usually implemented on top of Hadoop’s HDFS to build upon some of the processing drawbacks of MapReduce — thereby resulting in a multi-folds increase in the processing speed (especially for massive volumes of live data streaming).
Although Spark, as a cluster computing framework, can be implemented on a standalone basis. However, it is mostly used within a Hadoop ecosystem to get the best of both worlds.
Data visualization is the graphical representation of data and helps in obtaining a better understanding of our data and its various intricacies, interrelationships, nomenclature, issues, etc.
Some of the major data visualization tools and solutions available to a data scientist are:

With that, we have concluded our whirlwind and a high-level tour of data science. It is an extremely broad, diversified, and a rapidly evolving field — the above is not meant to be a comprehensive listing of all its facets. Instead, this is just a primer for any budding data scientist. Hopefully, it will act as a reference guide for others looking for a high-level explanation of some of its major components.
I hope to write more articles in the future with a specific focus on the machine learning aspect — watch this space.
In the meanwhile, feel free to reach out to me if you would like to discuss anything related to data science and specifically machine learning.
A finance professional by education with a keen interest in data analytics and machine learning. www.finltyicshub.com
